title: Paul Bartlett
text:
BioEducationWorkVolunteering


I am a dabbler in many things, mainly tech-related, and a long-time Googler of various hats.


Sidney Sussex College, Cambridge (1991–1994)
MA(Hons) in Natural Sciences (Physics)
King Edwards School, Bath (1984–1991)


Google, London
2022–present: Technical Programme Manager (Ads Quality Infra SRE)
2017–2022: Site Reliability Manager (Ads SRE Extraction)
2010–2017: Tech lead / Manager (Ads, various)
2007–2010: Software Engineer (Checkout, Apps, Ads)
2004–2007: Business Objects, Ealing
Development Manager (Enterprise Performance Management)
2001–2004: Thomson Financial, Woking
Software Engineer (Trading)
2000–2001: INPHASE, Ascot / Denham
Software Engineer (PerformancePlus EPM)
1997–2000: CMG, London
Consultant (Utilities)
1994–1997: ICL / Fujitsu, Bracknell
Software Engineer (OfficePower X.400)


2020–present: Berkshire Cambridge Society (Communications Officer)
2009–2016: Colnbrook Scouts Group (Cub Scout Leader)

title: Still here!
text:
Yup, I’m still here, but I’ve been writing in shorter format over on Mastodon, have jumped on the Pixelfed bandwagon, and have been spending my free time getting my newly separated work and home desk areas set up nicely (photos to follow once it’s finished!).
So here’s a little something while I’m here: you don’t need to go full “The Toyota Way” to take this simple but important advice.

Picard management tip: Don’t assume anything is possible or impossible until you’ve asked the people who will be doing the work.

_Source: https://mas.to/@PicardTips/113856811651828820_

title: USB C (offee)
text: The wonders of the modern world: I had to recharge my coffee jar today :)

title: Happy New Year!
text:
Happy New Year, if it’s not too late to still be saying it :)
Tomorrow is the “official” start of my 2025, and the news is I’m going to start trying to write a bit more (I’ll let you decide whether that is good or bad news!).
It’ll eventually be hosted on Github Pages, but I think a blog with just one post looks a little sad so I’ll likely not click the button on that until there’s a little bit more there.
Also eventually, I hope it’ll be a mix of blog posts and longer articles, and I’m also trying to tie it into habit tracking rather than doing “traditional” resolutions this year.
Bye for now!
- Paul.

title: Podcast idea
text: I’m thinking of starting a podcast under the pseudonym Joe Vogon. I’d discuss the pros and cons of destroying the Earth to make way for a hyperspace bypass, and share some of my very bad poetry.

title: Why naming is hard
text:
Conventional wisdom would have us believe that one* of the hardest things in computer science is naming things.
Whilst probably true, I think this is mistaking a symptom for the cause. In a simple system naming is easy, but the problem is that simplicity is difficult. As Dijkstra put it:

Simplicity is a great virtue but it requires hard work to achieve it and education to appreciate it. And to make matters worse: complexity sells better.

* Strictly 0–2 as another one* of them is off-by-one errors. See also Martin Fowler’s bliki: “Two Hard Things”

title: Fosstodon reply where I mention this setup
text:
Originally posted here (on Fosstodon).

I’ve gone for writing in Obsidian (mainly), generating with Quarto and publishing to GH Pages: https://pdbartlett.github.io. It’s still early days, and I’m still copy/pasting into the “little textbox” here, but other than that it’s going okay. Must check if Mastodon has its own posting API (would be nice if it supported MetaWeblog ofc!) as opposed to interop via ActivityPub.

title: A few more details…
text:
To expand a little on what I said yesterday, the following things are definitely top of mind to cover:

the role(s) of planning in having impact
analogies from business to science (e.g. alignment with velocity)
a “patterns” viewpoint (maybe starting with Balanced Scorecard)
the tech behind the site when it lands!

title: Blog now live!
text: Woo-hoo! After minimal messing with configs, my Obsidian&Quarto-powered blog is now live here at pdbartlett.github.io. I’ll continue to post a copy of short-form content on Fosstodon, though, and an excerpt-plus-link for anything longer (when I get round to writing some).
